conclusion: The problem involves analyzing v-t graphs for objects A and B to determine if their accelerations are first increasing and then decreasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.

The v-t graphs show two curves: Object A has the upper curve with larger maximum velocity, and Object B has the lower curve with smaller maximum velocity. Both start at the origin (v=0, t=0) and end at the t-axis at time t1 (v=0, t=t1). Red tangent lines are shown at different points along these curves.

In a velocity-time graph, the acceleration at any point is given by the slope of the tangent line at that point. Positive slope indicates positive acceleration, negative slope indicates negative acceleration, and steeper slope indicates larger magnitude of acceleration.
To determine if acceleration is first increasing and then decreasing, the slope of the tangent line must first increase, reach a maximum, and then decrease over time.
At t=0, the slope of both curves is positive (upward curve from origin). At t=t1, the slope of both curves is negative (downward curve to t-axis).

For acceleration to first increase and then decrease, the v-t curve should first be concave up and then concave down, indicating the slope of the tangent line increases, reaches a maximum, and then decreases.
Both curves appear to be smooth parabola-like shapes that rise from zero, reach a maximum, and then fall back to zero.
The initial portion of both curves from t=0 appears to be concave down, meaning the slope of the tangent line (acceleration) is decreasing from the start.
There is no visible portion of the curves where they are concave up, which would indicate increasing acceleration.

No, the accelerations of both objects A and B are not first increasing and then decreasing. Based on the concavity of the v-t graphs, both objects appear to have decreasing acceleration from the beginning of the time interval.
